imagingbook.pub.geometry.mappings.linear

Class AffineMapping

  • java.lang.Object
    • imagingbook.pub.geometry.mappings.Mapping
      • imagingbook.pub.geometry.mappings.linear.LinearMapping
        • imagingbook.pub.geometry.mappings.linear.ProjectiveMapping
          • imagingbook.pub.geometry.mappings.linear.AffineMapping
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    JacobianSupport, Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Rotation, Scaling, Shear, Translation

    public class AffineMapping
extends ProjectiveMapping
    This class represents an affine transformation in 2D, which can be defined by three pairs of corresponding points. It can be assumed that every instance of this class is indeed an affine mapping.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected static double AffineTolerance
      Deviation limit for checking 0 and 1 values.

        A2 - point 2 of source triangle A
        A3 - point 3 of source triangle A
        B1 - point 1 of source triangle B
        B2 - point 2 of source triangle B

      • isAffine

        public static boolean isAffine(LinearMapping lm)
        Checks if the given linear mapping could be affine, i.e. if the bottom row of its transformation matrix is (0, 0, 1). Note that this is a necessary but not sufficient requirement. The threshold AffineTolerance is used in this check.
        Parameters:
        lm - a linear mapping
        Returns:
        true if the mapping could be affine

      • concat

        public AffineMapping concat(AffineMapping B)
        Concatenates this mapping A with another affine mapping B and returns a new mapping C, such that C(x) = B(A(x)).
        Parameters:
        B - the second mapping
        Returns:
        the concatenated affine mapping

      • getInverse

        public AffineMapping getInverse()
        Calculates and returns the inverse mapping. Note that the inverse A' of a projective transformation matrix A is again a linear transformation but its a'2' element is generally not 1. Scaling A' to A'' = A' / a22' yields a projective transformation that reverses A. While A * A' = I, the result of A * A'' is a scaled identity matrix. Note that inverting an affine transformation always yields another affine transformation.
        Overrides:
        getInverse in class ProjectiveMapping
        Returns:
        the inverse projective transformation

        Returns:
        a new affine mapping
